title: Better error message when : appears where = is supposed to appear

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-newcomer-roadblock
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error hard to understand for new users

body:
Consider this code:

```rust
pub fn foo(num: i32) -> i32 {
    let foo: i32::from_be(num);
}
```
[Godbolt link](https://rust.godbolt.org/z/AjzqfO)

The compiler complains like this:

```
error[E0573]: expected type, found local variable `num`
 --> <source>:2:27
  |
2 |     let foo: i32::from_be(num);
  |                           ^^^ not a type

error: parenthesized parameters may only be used with a trait
 --> <source>:2:26
  |
2 |     let foo: i32::from_be(num);
  |                          ^^^^^
  |
  = note: #[deny(parenthesized_params_in_types_and_modules)] on by default
  = warning: this was previously accepted by the compiler but is being phased out; it will become a hard error in a future release!
  = note: for more information, see issue #42238 <https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/42238>

error[E0223]: ambiguous associated type
 --> <source>:2:14
  |
2 |     let foo: i32::from_be(num);
  |              ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ help: use fully-qualified syntax: `<i32 as Trait>::from_be`

error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> <source>:1:29
  |
1 |   pub fn foo(num: i32) -> i32 {
  |  _____________________________^
2 | |     let foo: i32::from_be(num);
3 | | }
  | |_^ expected i32, found ()
  |
  = note: expected type `i32`
             found type `()`

error: aborting due to 4 previous errors
Some errors occurred: E0223, E0308, E0573.
For more information about an error, try `rustc --explain E0223`.
```

It would be good if the compiler was able to suggest that you may want to replace `:` with `=` instead of just making suggestions based on the premise that `:` was right.
